reviews.text: What really sells it is the film's surprising final act, one that pulls the rug from under our feets and becomes a beautiful tale of inspiration and creativity through the minds of innocence...
reviews.author: Brendan Cassidy

reviews.text: It’s to Lord and Miller’s credit that The Lego Movie rarely feels hemmed in by the limitations of its premise.
reviews.author: Miles Surrey

reviews.text: The colorful adventure (and it is colorful, in all the bright, primary hues of the toy bricks) is a collision of order and anarchy as a superhero fable that spills over in to the real world in a marvelously clever and resonant turn.
reviews.author: Sean Axmaker

reviews.text: Phil Lord and Chris Miller’s masterwork features enough creativity to cover a year’s worth of movies and brings the Lego world to life in a way that makes a stunning jump from product placement to hard-won ingenuity.
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: Great voice acting, sharp writing, and a wonderful story all the way down to its core.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: In the end, the costs (both monetary and social) of The LEGO Movie are less than desirable, but it works on multiple levels as the best animated films often do, and provides a number of distinctive visual touches to keep the viewer involved and laughing.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: It’s the best possible ad for Legos that the company could have ever hoped for, and it achieves that by embedding in its very concept the kind of play that has kept both kids and adults playing with Legos for years.
reviews.author: Dan Bayer

reviews.text: The LEGO Movie is a beautifully animated film that remains one of the best films of 2014.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: A poignant children's film, which injected American animation with a surge of energy, style, and confidence, The LEGO Movie took the most surprising stances...
reviews.author: Kanishk Devgan

reviews.text: The weirdest, most psychedelic kid's entertainment since H.R. Pufnstuf.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: Surprisingly action-packed and high-octane.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: It is a film best experienced and best experienced as a beloved experience between adults and the children they love.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: As we dig deeper, we come to understand why all of this exists, and why there is such a battle between following the rules and using your own imagination.
reviews.author: Allen Almachar

reviews.text: Five hours later and still singing EVERYTHING IS AWESOME!
reviews.author: Kelechi Ehenulo

reviews.text: The LEGO Movie is the first great comedy, the first great action film and the first great family film of the year.
reviews.author: Damond Fudge

reviews.text: The Lego Movie is stupid fun to watch, hilarious in all the right ways and one of the most original animated blockbusters anyone has constructed in quite some time.
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: This film is frequently hilarious, deeply subversive and multilayered, and it's an absolute delight from start to finish.
reviews.author: Leslie Combemale

reviews.text: Ticklish, touching and mostly terrific, The LEGO Movie is great fun for everyone.
reviews.author: Christopher Preston

reviews.text: I was completely surprised by this movie.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: It's an animated treat that will please all... A movie that expands on the world of the popular toy, creating a universe full of imagination and surprise.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: By the end, directors/writers Phil Lord & Christopher Miller...have tried to have things so many different ways that The LEGO Movie philosophically breaks apart due to unbalanced construction.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: Basically, they got you to pay money to watch a one hundred minute commercial. They got you to do it, and like it.
reviews.author: Emmet Asher-Perrin

reviews.text: It is an instant animated classic, and in the years to come I'm sure it will be looked back on with fond memories and inspire others to follow in its path.
reviews.author: Jennifer Heaton

reviews.text: Clearly having fun with the low expectations garnered by the idea of a full-length film devoted to schilling for a toy, the film's directors have nonetheless created a solidly enjoyable and often hilarious 100 minutes of entertainment.
reviews.author: Deborah Krieger

reviews.text: The Lego Movie is both a perfect satire of noisy toy-driven summer action movies, and also an absolutely perfect summer movie in its own right.
reviews.author: Charlie Jane Anders

reviews.text: They took a concept that I never thought would work on the big screen and it works so well.
reviews.author: Andre Meadows

reviews.text: Is there a word beyond hysterical? This isn't just hysterical, it's life-shortening.
reviews.author: Camilla Long

reviews.text: The ultimate result may be kind of predictable, but it's still fun.
reviews.author: Josh Terry

reviews.text: There's much to enjoy in this film for all age groups - everything from the pop culture references, the multitudes of characters, light-hearted sarcasm and above all, the fantastic script.
reviews.author: Reagan Gavin Rasquinha

reviews.text: Colourful, inventive and action-packed.
reviews.author: Rochelle Siemienowicz

reviews.text: The LEGO Movie is, in fact, a highly entertaining, very fun and unexpectedly touching movie that kids and adults can enjoy equally.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: [The Lego Movie] embraces what parents and kids really love about Lego; creativity, imagination and individuality. Or, as my seven year-old simply said, "awesomeness".
reviews.author: Francesca Rudkin

reviews.text: It's equal parts clever, hilarious and full of heart.
reviews.author: Tara Thorne

reviews.text: The LEGO Movie teaches our kids what it means to be unique, imaginative, and heroically important by paving their own paths.
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: An especially clever ontological construct is having all the various LEGO game-sets represent various dimensions of the LEGO cosmos, sort of like unitary paradises.
reviews.author: Mark Jackson

reviews.text: The idea that the deadliest weapon in this Lego galaxy is glue, which will make everything permanent and unmovable, shows that childish wit is probably the purest wit of all.
reviews.author: Kong Rithdee

reviews.text: It's hard to imagine a more inspired Lego film, or one less concerned with selling toys.
reviews.author: J. Olson

reviews.text: At least, lighthearted silliness serves as a palliative for the reflexive cynicism that emerges in viewers confronted with such a blatant corporate agenda. But the filmmakers do not have the good sense to stop there.
reviews.author: Martin Tsai

reviews.text: Hilarious and heartfelt in the right ways, The Lego Movie also successfully pokes fun at the genre cliches we're all so used to.
reviews.author: Chris Stuckmann

reviews.text: It's one of the few movies based on a toy with no explicit story behind it. And it is, so far, the only one that's really good.
reviews.author: Katey Rich

reviews.text: The movie is a wonderful surprise, cleverly written and executed brick by brick with a visual panache.
reviews.author: Peter Hartlaub

reviews.text: Gloriously wise, beautifully crafted, and unabashedly fun.
reviews.author: Rob Hunter

reviews.text: Lord and Miller's sensibilities are continually clever, and The Lego Movie works hard to gradually deliver surprising payoffs to what seem to be throwaway bits.
reviews.author: Kate Erbland

reviews.text: It's not that audiences (at least the older ones) don't realise they're watching a big and glossy advertisement. Because it's bright, fun and smart, they just don't care.
reviews.author: Luke Buckmaster

reviews.text: From scene one, The Lego Movie is maniacal in its comic delivery.
reviews.author: Michael Arbeiter

reviews.text: The Lego Movie has enough wit and wisdom to send a recession-age message to families on the importance of thinking through problems with creativity.
reviews.author: Maricar Estrella

reviews.text: In spite of itself, The Lego Movie is curiously self-correcting and still gets to be all things to almost all people. It's a crowded construction site of hilariously mixed-up everywhatever.
reviews.author: Dave White

reviews.text: Sweet, funny, preposterously complex and uniquely ridiculous, The Lego Movie feels like a quantum step up for both CG animation and movies based on marketing pitches.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: So much of The Lego Movie really is awesome.
reviews.author: Alynda Wheat

reviews.text: This is as wildly imaginative and fun as any film you're likely to see this year, even if it is based entirely on corporate synergy.
reviews.author: Daniel Barnes

reviews.text: The creators of The LEGO Movie know the building blocks of a great movie: charm, side-splitting jokes, lovable people (er, I mean LEGO figures) and an engaging storyline.
reviews.author: Vince Horiuchi

reviews.text: The Lego Movie is an intricate piece that delights in both celebrating and mocking movie archetypes, the commercialisation of childhood experience, and the authoritarian hands of parents.
reviews.author: Craig Mathieson

reviews.text: Lord and Miller have achieved the seemingly impossible and assembled a genuinely funny, touching, inspirational and absolutely lunatic love letter to those tiny bricks, as well as to imagination and creativity in general.
reviews.author: Iain McNally

reviews.text: It is a canny piece of pop art, and The Lego Movie should end up delighting old and young viewers in equal measure.
reviews.author: Drew McWeeny

reviews.text: [The Lego Movie hits] the sweet spot between adults who grew up with Lego and children who love Lego, and carefully ignoring the irony of such an overtly branded indictment of corporate strangulation of creativity.
reviews.author: Alex Doenau

reviews.text: For those of us who remember the limitlessness of our imaginations as we played with little plastic blocks, this is a joy to behold.
reviews.author: AP Kryza

reviews.text: The storyline is wonderfully subversive, and the jokes come so fast and furious that it's a challenge to keep up with the humor of The Lego Movie.
reviews.author: Michael Smith

reviews.text: It's oddly refreshing when a movie intended to sell toys winds up being thoroughly delightful on its own.
reviews.author: Dan Lybarger

reviews.text: You'll leave the theater smiling and singing "Everything Is Awesome," because when it comes to The Lego Movie, everything is.
reviews.author: David Blaustein

reviews.text: Carries on in the grand Bob Clampett Warner Brothers "Porky in Wackyland" tradition. Surrealism for the six year old and the sixty year old.
reviews.author: Louis Proyect

reviews.text: It's brilliantly animated and incredibly well shot - whether it's the dazzling 'Busytown' cityscapes that children's author-illustrator Richard Scarry might once have created or simply two characters defying the breathtakingly shallow depth of field.
reviews.author: Graham Young

reviews.text: A 100-minute advertisement you've paid to watch--now that's ingenuity.
reviews.author: Bill Chambers

reviews.text: The Lego Movie presents one of the brightest-colored dystopian nightmares ever marketed to children ... highly imaginative, wildly fun, and clever on multiple levels.
reviews.author: Austin Trunick

reviews.text: By going off the proverbial reservation, making what amounts to a Lego movie for adults, even at the risk of displeasing those who wanted nothing more than a nostalgic wink fest, The Lego Movie merits praise as a true work of thematic richness.
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: Everything is awesome! Well, not quite everything - but more than enough to make THE LEGO MOVIE the biggest and best surprise this year.
reviews.author: Steve Biodrowski

reviews.text: [I]t's an exhilarating, absolute joy to watch it all come together.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: While "The Lego Movie" may have a pretty basic story, its beautifully animated world and talented vocal cast give it enough depth to provide lots of fun and excitement.
reviews.author: Jeff Beck

reviews.text: ...the movie's relentlessly frenetic vibe grows more and more exhausting as time progresses...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: In what is sure to turn out to be this generation's Toy Story, this crazy-funny animated lark takes us into a hyper-happy world where everything is so awesome there's even a pop anthem called Everything is Awesome... fresh and fast and funny.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: ... let's not pave all the roads with yellow bricks just yet.
reviews.author: Blake Howard

reviews.text: Delightful, inspired, affecting, utterly hilarious stuff, and certainly the first feature starring Batman to earn a couple of those compliments.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: Just as the conceptual agility of The LEGO Movie never ceases to astonish - it will take at least three viewings to fully take in every last detail applied here - the visuals both innovate and resonate to heights only previously scaled by Pixar.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: it's worth your time to discover instead of me preempting by synopsis and/or recitation. I hate it when an internet post ends this way, but it's all you're going to get from this review: "Enjoy!"
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: A wry, playful and intelligent piece of filmmaking that, like Toy Story before it, rises far above its station.
reviews.author: Tom Glasson

reviews.text: The Lego Movie is a brilliant technical achievement.
reviews.author: Evan Williams

reviews.text: It's fast, smart, really funny, full of great action and contains a song, 'Everything is Awesome', with the single catchiest hook in the history of songwriting. Seriously, in this movie at least, everything really is awesome.
reviews.author: Anthony Morris

reviews.text: This is one of the most creative animated features in recent years. I never imagined that so much could be made from the concept.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: The giggle-inducing gags will infect humans of any age with their zany sense of humour.
reviews.author: Liam Maguren

reviews.text: It's relieving to say that it brims with visual charm and creativity.
reviews.author: Damien Straker

reviews.text: State-of-the-art software has been used to make the characters look like actual plastic figurines brought to life through the magic of stop-motion animation. In other words, this is a digital movie with an analogue soul.
reviews.author: Jake Wilson

synopsis: Emmet (Chris Pratt), an ordinary LEGO figurine who always follows the rules, is mistakenly identified as the Special -- an extraordinary being and the key to saving the world. He finds himself drafted into a fellowship of strangers who are on a mission to stop an evil tyrant's (Will Ferrell) plans to conquer the world. Unfortunately for Emmet, he is hopelessly -- and hilariously -- unprepared for such a task, but he'll give it his all nonetheless.
